standard_metadata.standard_description: Apply and extend previous understandings of multiplication to multiply a fraction by a whole number.
standard_metadata.standard_title: Multiply fractions and whole numbers word problems

question.content: You are planning a movie marathon.  Each movie lasts $\dfrac32$ hours.  You want to watch $4$ movies nonstop.   **How many hours will your movie marathon last?**      hours

hints.content: Each movie lasts $\maroonD{\dfrac32}$ hours.   [[☃ image 1]]

images.alt: A number line from zero-halves to twelve-halves with tick marks at every one-half unit. Labels are at each two-halves unit. Tick mark three-halves is labeled in pink with a pink dot.

hints.content: You want to watch $\blueD{4}$ movies nonstop.   [[☃ image 1]]  You can multiply $\blueD{4 \times}\maroonD{\dfrac32}$ to figure out how long your movie marathon will last.

images.alt: A number line labeled zero-halves to twelve-halves with tick marks at every one-half unit. Labels are at each three-halves units. A blue arrow jumps right, starting at zero-halves to three-halves, from three-halves to six-halves, from six-halves to nine-halves and then from nine-halves to twelve-halves. Each jump is labeled plus three-halves.

hints.content: $\begin{align} &\quad\blueD{4 \times} \maroonD{\dfrac32}\\\\ &=\dfrac{\blueD{4 \times}\maroonD3} {\maroonD2}\\\\ &={\dfrac{12}{2}}\\\\ &=6 \end{align}$
Your movie marathon will last $6$ hours.

question.content: Katie's hair grows $\dfrac78$ of a centimeter each month.    **How many centimeters will Katie's hair grow over $5$ months?**    $\text{cm}$

hints.content: Katie's hair grows $\maroonD{\dfrac78}$ of a centimeter each month. We want to know how much her hair will grow over $\blueD5$ months.    Month $\blueD1$ | Month $\blueD2$  | Month $\blueD3$ |Month $\blueD4$ | Month $\blueD5$ :-: |:-: |:-: |:-: |:-:  ||||  We can multiply $\blueD{5 \times}\maroonD{\dfrac78}$ to figure this out.

images.alt: Five equal-sized rectangles, each divided into eight equal parts with seven parts shaded pink. Below the rectangles, each rectangle is labeled seven-eighths. Above the rectangles, each rectangle is numbered Month 1 to Month 5..

hints.content: $\begin{align} &\quad\blueD{5 \times} \maroonD{\dfrac78}\\\\ &=\dfrac{\blueD{5 \times}\maroonD7} {\maroonD8}\\\\ &={\dfrac{35}{8}} \end{align}$
Katie's hair will grow $\dfrac{35}8 \text{cm}$.  This can also be written as $4\dfrac38 \text{cm}$.

question.content: Darren practiced piano $5$ days this week. He practiced $\dfrac34$ of an hour each day.    **How many hours did Darren practice piano this week?**       hours

hints.content: Darren practiced $\maroonD{\dfrac34}$ of an hour each day.  He practiced $\blueD5$ days.   Day $\blueD1$ | Day $\blueD2$  | Day $\blueD3$  | Day $\blueD4$ | Day $\blueD5$  :-: |:-: |:-: |:-: |:-:   | | | |   We can multiply $\blueD{5 \times}\maroonD{\dfrac34}$ to figure out how many hours Darren practiced this week.

images.alt: Five equal-sized circles, each divided into four equal parts with three parts shaded pink. Each circle is labeled three-fourths.

hints.content: $\begin{align} &\quad\blueD{5 \times} \maroonD{\dfrac34}\\\\ &=\dfrac{\blueD{5 \times}\maroonD3} {\maroonD4}\\\\ &={\dfrac{15}{4}} \end{align}$
Darren practiced piano $\dfrac{15}{4}$ hours this week.  This can also be written as $3\dfrac34$ hours.

question.content: Talia attended a $5$-day math camp that lasted $\dfrac56$ of an hour each day.  **How many total hours did Talia spend at math camp?**       hours

hints.content: Talia's math camp lasted $\maroonD{\dfrac56}$ of an hour each day for $\blueD5$ days.  Day $\blueD1$ | Day $\blueD2$ | Day $\blueD3$ | Day $\blueD4$ | Day $\blueD5$ |    :-: |:-: |:-: |:-: |:-:  |  | ||  We can multiply $\blueD5 \times\maroonD{\dfrac56}$ to figure out Talia's total hours in math camp.

images.alt: Five equal-sized circles, each divided into six equal parts with five parts shaded pink. Below each circle is the label five-sixths. Above the circles, the circles are numbered Day 1 to Day 5.

hints.content: $\begin{align} &\quad\blueD5 \times \maroonD{\dfrac56}\\\\ &=\dfrac{\blueD5 \times\maroonD5} {\maroonD6}\\\\ &={\dfrac{25}{6}} \end{align}$
Talia spent $\dfrac{25}6$ hours at math camp.  This can also be written as $4\dfrac16$ hours.

question.content: A batch of brownies requires $\dfrac13$ of a can of cocoa powder.  You want to make $4$ batches.  **How many cans of cocoa powder do you need?**     cans

hints.content: Each batch requires $\maroonD{\dfrac13}$ of a can of cocoa powder.  You want to make $\blueD4$ batches.  Batch $\blueD1$ | Batch $\blueD2$  | Batch $\blueD3$ |Batch $\blueD4$  :-: |:-: |:-: |:-: |:-:   |  |  |   You can multiply $\blueD4 \times\maroonD{\dfrac13}$ to figure out how many cans of cocoa powder you need.

images.alt: Four equal-sized rectangles, each divided into three equal parts with one part shaded pink. Below the rectangles, each rectangle is labeled one-third. Above the rectangles, each rectangle is numbered Batch 1 to Batch 4.

hints.content: $\begin{align} &\quad{\blueD4 \times} \maroonD{\dfrac13}\\\\ &=\dfrac{{\blueD4 \times}\maroonD1} {\maroonD3}\\\\ &={\dfrac{4}{3}} \end{align}$
You need $\dfrac{4}3$ cans of cocoa powder.  This can also be written as $1\dfrac13$ cans.

question.content: Aliana uses beads that are $\dfrac54$ centimeters long to make a necklace. She uses $3$ beads all together.  **How many centimeters of beads will Aliana use for the necklace?**     centimeters

hints.content: Each bead has a length of $\maroonD{\dfrac54}$ centimeters.   [[☃ image 1]]

images.alt: A number line from zero-fourths to sixteen-fourths with tick marks at every one-fourth unit. Labels are at each four-fourths units. Tick mark five-fourths is labeled in pink with a pink dot.

hints.content: Aliana uses  $\blueD{3}$ beads.    [[☃ image 1]]    We can multiply $\blueD{3 \times}\maroonD{\dfrac54}$ to figure out the total length of the beads.

images.alt: A number line from zero-fourth to fifteen-fourths with tick marks at every one-fourth unit. Labels are at every five-fourths units. A blue arrow jumps right, starting at zero-fourths to five-fourths, from five-fourths to ten-fourths, and then from ten-fourths to fifteen-fourths. Each jump is labeled plus five-fourths.

hints.content: ${\blueD3 \times} \maroonD{\dfrac54}=\dfrac{{\blueD3 \times }\:\maroonD5} {\maroonD4}={\dfrac{15}{4}}$
Aliana will use $\dfrac{15}4$ centimeters of beads for the necklace.  This can also be written as $3\dfrac34$ centimeters.

question.content: A batch of peanut butter cookies requires $\dfrac34$ of a jar of peanut butter.  You want to make $3$ batches.  **How many jars of peanut butter do you need?**     jars

hints.content: Each batch requires $\maroonD{\dfrac34}$ of a jar of peanut butter.  You want to make $\blueD3$ batches.  Batch $\blueD1$ | Batch $\blueD2$  | Batch $\blueD3$  :-: |:-: |:-: |:-: |:-:   | |   You can multiply $\blueD3 \times\maroonD{\dfrac34}$ to figure out how many jars of peanut butter you need.

images.alt: Three equal-sized rectangles, each divided into four equal parts with three parts shaded pink. Each rectangle is labeled three-fourths.

hints.content: $\begin{align} &\quad{\blueD3 \times} \maroonD{\dfrac34}\\\\ &=\dfrac{{\blueD3~ \times }~\maroonD 3} {\maroonD4}\\\\ &={\dfrac{9}{4}} \end{align}$
You need $\dfrac{9}4$ jars  of peanut butter.  This can also be written as $2\dfrac14$ jars.

question.content: Ameer uses $\dfrac14$ of a bottle of shampoo to give each of his dogs a bath.  He has $5$ dogs all together.  **How many bottles of shampoo does Ameer need?**     bottles

hints.content: Ameer uses $\maroonD{\dfrac14}$ of a bottle of shampoo on each dog.  He has $\blueD5$ dogs.  Dog $\blueD1$ | Dog $\blueD2$  | Dog $\blueD3$ | Dog $\blueD4$ | Dog $\blueD5$  :-: |:-: |:-: |:-: |:-:  |:-: |:-:  |  | |  |   You can multiply $\blueD5 \times\maroonD{\dfrac14}$ to figure out how many bottles of shampoo Ameer needs.

images.alt: Five equal-sized rectangles, each divided into four equal parts with one part shaded pink. Below the rectangles, each rectangle is labeled one-fourth. Above the rectangles, each rectangle is numbered Dog 1 to Dog 5.

hints.content: ${\blueD5 \times} \maroonD{\dfrac14}=\dfrac{{\blueD5 \times }\:\maroonD1} {\maroonD4}={\dfrac{5}{4}}$
Ameer needs $\dfrac{5}4$ bottles of shampoo.  This can also be written as $1\dfrac14$ bottles.

question.content: An art teacher buys clay for an animation project. Each box of clay weighs $\dfrac52$ kilograms.  She buys $2$ boxes of clay.  **How many kilograms of clay did the teacher buy?**     kilograms

hints.content: Each box of clay weighs $\maroonD{\dfrac52}$ kilograms. The teacher buys $\blueD2$ boxes.  Box $\blueD1$ | Box $\blueD2$   :-: |:-:  |  You can multiply $\blueD2 \times\maroonD{\dfrac52}$ to figure out how many kilograms of clay the teacher buys.

images.alt: A rectangle divided into two equal parts with both parts shaded pink. Under the rectangle is a label of two-halves. Above the rectangle is the label Box 1 with 1 written in blue.
A rectangle divided into two equal parts with both parts shaded pink. Under the rectangle is a label of two-halves.
A rectangle divided into two equal parts with one part shaded pink. Under the rectangle is a label of one-half.
A rectangle divided into two equal parts with both parts shaded pink. Under the rectangle is a label of two-halves. Above the rectangle is the label Box 2 with 2 written in blue.
A rectangle divided into two equal parts with both parts shaded pink. Under the rectangle is a label of two-halves.
A rectangle divided into two equal parts with one part shaded pink. Under the rectangle is a label of one-half.

hints.content: ${\blueD2 \times} \maroonD{\dfrac52}=\dfrac{{\blueD2 \times }\:\maroonD5} {\maroonD2}={\dfrac{10}{2}}$
The teacher buys $\dfrac{10}2$ kilograms of clay.  This can also be written as $5$ kilograms.

question.content: Sandy bought $6$ medium cartons of blueberries. Each medium carton held $\dfrac3{4}$ liter of blueberries.   Lindsay bought $2$ large cartons of blueberries. Each large carton held $\dfrac9{4}$ liters of blueberries.   **Who bought more liters of blueberries?**

options.content: They bought the same number of liters of blueberries.

hints.content: ###Sandy  Sandy bought $6$ cartons with $\dfrac34$ liter of blueberries in each carton.   [[☃ image 1]]  We can multiply $\blueD{6 \times \dfrac34}$ to figure out how many liters of blueberries Sandy bought:  $\begin{align} &\blueD{6 \times \dfrac34}\\\\ =&\dfrac{\blueD{6 \times}\blueD3} {\blueD4}\\\\ =&\blueD{\dfrac{18}{4}} \end{align}$  Sandy bought $\blueD{\dfrac{18}{4}}$ liters of blueberries.

images.alt: A number line from zero-fourths to eighteen-fourths with tick marks at each one-fourth unit. Zero-fourths, three-fourths, six-fourths, nine-fourths, twelve-fourths, fifteen-fourths, and eighteen-fourths are labeled. A blue arrow jumps right, connecting each of the labeled tick marks. Above each jump is the label plus three-fourths in blue.

hints.content: ###Lindsay  Lindsay bought $2$ cartons with $\dfrac94$ liter of blueberries in each carton.   [[☃ image 1]]  We can multiply $\maroonD{2 \times \dfrac94}$ to figure out how many liters of blueberries Lindsay bought:  $\begin{align} &\maroonD{2 \times \dfrac94}\\\\ =&\dfrac{\maroonD{2 \times}\maroonD9} {\maroonD4}\\\\ =&\maroonD{\dfrac{18}{4}} \end{align}$

images.alt: A number line from zero-fourths to eighteen-fourths with tick marks at every one-fourth unit. Zero-fourths, nine-fourths and eighteen-fourths are labeled.  A pink arrow jumps right, connecting each of the labeled tick marks. Above each jump is the label plus nine-fourths in pink.

hints.content: Sandy |  | Lindsay :-: | :-: | :-: $\blueD{\dfrac{18}{4}}$ liters | $=$ | $\maroonD{\dfrac{18}{4}}$ liters
They bought the same number of liters of blueberries.

question.content: Last week, Becky went to dance class $4$ times. Each class was $\dfrac32$ hours.  This week, Becky went to dance class $5$ times. Each class was $1$ hour.  **Which week did Becky spend more total time in dance class?**

options.content: She spent the same amount of time in dance class each week.

hints.content: ###Last week  Last week, Becky went to class $4$ times. Each class was $\dfrac32$ an hour long.    [[☃ image 1]]  We can multiply $\blueD{4 \times \dfrac32}$ to figure out the  time Becky spent in dance class last week:   $\begin{align} &\quad\blueD{4 \times \dfrac32}\\\\ &=\dfrac{\blueD{4 \times}\blueD 3} {\blueD2}\\\\ &=\blueD{\dfrac{12}{2}}\\\\ &=\blueD{6} \end{align}$  Becky went to class for $\blueD{6}$ hours last week.

images.alt: A number line from zero-halves to twelve-halves with tick marks are every one-half unit. Labels are at the tick marks for every three-halves units. A blue arrow jumps right, starting from zero-halves to three-halves, from three-halves to six-halves, from six-halves to nine-halves, and then from nine-halves to twelve-halves. Each jump is labeled plus three-halves.

hints.content: ###This week  This week, Becky went to class $5$ times. Each class was $1$ an hour long.    [[☃ image 1]]  We can multiply $\maroonD{5 \times 1}$ to figure out the  time Becky spent in dance class this week:   $\maroonD5\times\maroonD1=\maroonD5$  Becky went to class for $\maroonD{5}$ hours this week.

images.alt: A number line labeled from zero over one to five over one. Each tick mark is labeled at the whole number, so that zero over one, one over one, two over one, three over one, four over one and five over one are labeled. Each tick mark is connected to the next by a series of jumps using a pink arrow above the number line. Above each jump is a label of plus 1.

hints.content: Last week |  | This week :-: | :-: | :-: $\blueD{6}$ hours | $>$ | $\maroonD{5}$ hours
Becky spent more total time in dance class last week.

question.content: Raul bought $6$ tangerines and ate $\dfrac23$ of them.  Omar bought $8$ tangerines and ate $\dfrac14$ of them.  **Who ate more tangerines?**

options.content: They ate the same number of tangerines.

hints.content: Eating a fraction of the tangerines is the same as eating that fraction times the number of tangerines each person had.

###Raul  Raul ate $\blueD{\dfrac23 \text{ of }6}$ tangerines.   [[☃ image 1]]  We can multiply $\blueD{\dfrac23\times6}$ to figure out the  amount of tangerines Raul ate:   $\begin{align} \blueD{\dfrac23\text{ of }6} &=~ \blueD{\dfrac23 \times 6}\\\\ &=\blueD{\dfrac{2\times6}{3}}\\\\ &= \blueD{\dfrac{12}{3}}\\\\ &= \blueD4 \end{align}$  Raul ate $\blueD4$ tangerines.

images.alt: Six equal-sized circles arranged in a row. The first four  circles are shaded blue. The other two circles are not shaded. There are dashed lines between the second and third circles and between the fourth and fifth circles.

hints.content: ###Omar   Omar ate $\maroonD{\dfrac14 \text{ of }8}$ tangerines.    [[☃ image 1]]  We can multiply $\maroonD{\dfrac14\times8}$ to figure out the  amount of tangerines Omar ate:  $\begin{align} \maroonD{\dfrac14\text{ of }8} ~&=~ \maroonD{\dfrac14 \times 8}\\\\ &=\maroonD{\dfrac{1\times8}{4}}\\\\ &= \maroonD{\dfrac{8}{4}}\\\\ &= \maroonD2 \end{align}$  Omar ate $\maroonD2$ tangerines.

images.alt: Eight equal-sized circles arranged in a row. The first two circles are shaded pink The other six circles are not shaded. There are dashed lines between the second and third circles, between the fourth and fifth circles, and between the sixth and seven circles.

hints.content: Raul |  | Omar :-: | :-: | :-: $\blueD4$ tangerines | $>$ | $\maroonD2$ tangerines
Raul ate more tangerines.

question.content: Liz and Erin are different ages but eat from the same size of bowl.  Liz ate $4 $ servings of cereal. Each serving was $\dfrac13 $ of a bowl.  Erin ate $3$ servings of cereal. Each serving was $\dfrac23 $ of a bowl.  **Who ate more bowls of cereal?**

options.content: They ate the same amount of cereal.

hints.content: ##Liz  Serving $\maroonD1$ | Serving $\maroonD2$  | Serving $\maroonD3$ | Serving $\maroonD4$  :-: |:-: |:-: |:-: |:-:   |  |  |   We can multiply $\maroonD{4 \times \dfrac13}$ to figure out how many bowls of cereal Liz ate:  $\begin{align} &\quad\maroonD{4 \times \dfrac13}\\\\ &=\dfrac{\maroonD{4 \times}\maroonD1} {\maroonD3}\\\\ &=\maroonD{\dfrac{4}{3}} \end{align}$  Liz ate $\maroonD{\dfrac43}$ bowls of cereal.

images.alt: Four equal-sized rectangles, each divided into three equal parts with one part shaded pink. Below the rectangles, each rectangle is labeled one-third. Above the rectangles, the rectangles are numbered Serving 1 to Serving 4.

hints.content: ###Erin  Serving $\blueD1$ | Serving $\blueD2$  | Serving $\blueD3$ :-: |:-: |:-: |:-: |:-:   |  |   We can multiply $\blueD{3 \times \dfrac23}$ to figure out how many bowls of cereal Erin ate:  $\begin{align} &\quad\blueD{3 \times \dfrac23}\\\\ &=\dfrac{\blueD{3 \times}\blueD2} {\blueD3}\\\\ &=\blueD{\dfrac{6}{3}} \end{align}$  Erin ate $\blueD{\dfrac63}$ bowls of cereal.

images.alt: Three equal-sized rectangles, each divided into three equal parts with two parts shaded blue. Below the rectangles, each rectangle is labeled two-thirds. Above the rectangles, each rectangle is numbered Serving 1 to Serving 3.

hints.content: Liz |  | Erin :-: | :-: | :-: $\maroonD{\dfrac{4}{3}}$ bowls | $<$ | $\blueD{\dfrac{6}{3}}$ bowls
Erin ate more bowls of cereal.

question.content: Tess ran $\dfrac43 $ kilometers each day for $2$ days.  Cam ran $\dfrac23 $ of a kilometer each day for $5$ days.  **Who ran more kilometers in total?**

options.content: They ran the same number of total kilometers.

hints.content: ###Tess  Tess ran $\dfrac43 $ kilometers each day for $2$ days.   [[☃ image 1]]  We can multiply $\maroonD{2 \times \dfrac43}$ to figure out the total distance Tess ran:  $\begin{align} &\quad\maroonD{2 \times \dfrac43}\\\\ &=\dfrac{\maroonD{2 \times}\maroonD4} {\maroonD3}\\\\ &=\maroonD{\dfrac{8}{3}} \end{align}$  Tess ran $\maroonD{\dfrac83}$ kilometers.

images.alt: A number line labeled zero-thirds to eight-thirds with tick marks every one-third unit. The tick marks at zero-thirds, four-thirds and eight-thirds are labeled.  A pink arrow jumps right starting at zero-thirds to four-thirds and then four-thirds to eight-thirds. Each jump is labeled plus four-thirds.

hints.content: ###Cam  Cam ran $\dfrac23 $ of a kilometer each day for $5$ days.  [[☃ image 1]]  We can multiply $\blueD{5 \times \dfrac23}$ to figure out the total distance Cam ran:  $\begin{align} &\quad\blueD{5 \times \dfrac23}\\\\ &=\dfrac{\blueD{5 \times}\blueD2} {\blueD3}\\\\ &=\blueD{\dfrac{10}{3}} \end{align}$  Cam ran $\blueD{\dfrac{10}3}$ kilometers.

images.alt: A number line labeled zero-thirds to ten-thirds with tick marks every one-third unit. Labels are at each two-thirds unit. A blue arrow jumps right, starting at zero-thirds to two-thirds, from two-thirds to four-thirds, from four-thirds to six-thirds, from six-thirds to eight-thirds, and then from eight-thirds to ten-thirds. Each jump is labeled plus two-thirds.

hints.content: Tess |  | Cam :-: | :-: | :-: $\maroonD{\dfrac{8}{3}} \text{ km}$ | $<$ | $\blueD{\dfrac{10}{3}} \text{ km}$
Cam ran more kilometers in total.

question.content: Rishi spent $\dfrac34$ of an hour each day for $2$ days working on his science project.  Kim spent $\dfrac14$ of an hour each day for $6$ days working on his science project.   **Who spent more time in total working on their science project?**

options.content: They spent the same amount of total time working on their projects.

hints.content: ###Rishi  Rishi spent $\dfrac34$ of an hour each day for $2$ days working on his science project.  [[☃ image 1]]   We can multiply $\blueD{2 \times \dfrac34}$ to figure out how many hours Rishi spent working on his science project:  $\begin{align} &\quad\blueD{2 \times \dfrac34}\\\\ &=\dfrac{\blueD{2 \times}\blueD3} {\blueD4}\\\\ &=\blueD{\dfrac{6}{4}} \end{align}$  Rishi spent $\blueD{\dfrac64}$ hour working on his science project.

images.alt: A number line labeled zero-fourths to six-fourths with tick marks every one-fourth unit. Tick marks Zero fourths, three-fourths, and six-fourths are labeled. A blue arrow jumps right, starting zero-fourths to three-fourths and then from three-fourths to six-fourths. Each jump is labeled plus three-fourths.

hints.content: ###Kim  [[☃ image 1]]  We can multiply $\maroonD{6 \times \dfrac14}$ to figure out how many hours Kim spent working on his science project:  $\begin{align} &\quad\maroonD{6 \times \dfrac14}\\\\ &=\dfrac{\maroonD{6 \times}\maroonD1} {\maroonD4}\\\\ &=\maroonD{\dfrac{6}{4}} \end{align}$  Kim spent $\maroonD{\dfrac64}$ hour working on her science project.

images.alt: A number line labeled zero-fourths to six-fourths with labeled tick marks every one-fourth unit. A pink arrow jumps right, starting at zero-fourths to one-fourth, from one-fourth to two-fourths, from two-fourths to three-fourths, from three-fourths to four-fourths, from four-fourths to five-fourths, and then from five-fourths to six-fourths. Each jump is labeled plus one-fourth in pink.

hints.content: Rishi |  | Kim :-: | :-: | :-: $\blueD{\dfrac{6}{4}}$ hours | $=$ | $\maroonD{\dfrac{6}{4}}$ hours
They spent the same amount of total time working on their projects.

question.content: Kai ran $\dfrac35$ of a kilometer yesterday.  Today, he ran $6$ times as far.    **How many kilometers did Kai run today?**      $\text{km}$

hints.content: Kai ran $\maroonD{\dfrac35}$ of a kilometer yesterday.    [[☃ image 1]]

images.alt: A number line labeled zero-fifths to twenty-fifths with tick marks at every one-fifth unit. Labels are at each five-fifths units. Tick mark three-fifths is also labeled on the number line in pink with a pink dot.

hints.content: He ran $\blueD{6}$ times as far today.   [[☃ image 1]]  We can multiply $\blueD{6 \times}\maroonD{\dfrac35}$ to figure out how far Kai ran today.

images.alt: A number line labeled zero-fifths to eighteen-fifths with tick marks at every one-fifth unit. Labels are at each three-fifths units. A blue arrow jumps right, starting at zero-fifths to three-fifths, from three-fifths-to six-fifths, from six-fifths to nine-fifths, from nine-fifths to twelve-fifths, from twelve-fifths to fifteen-fifths, and then from fifteen-fifths to eighteen-fifths. Each jump is labeled plus three-fifths.

hints.content: $\begin{align} &\quad\blueD{6 \times} \maroonD{\dfrac35}\\\\ &=\dfrac{\blueD{6 \times}\maroonD3} {\maroonD5}\\\\ &={\dfrac{18}{5}} \end{align}$
Kai ran $\dfrac{18}5 \text{ km}$ today.  We can also write this as $3\dfrac35 \text{ km}$.

question.content: The pepper plant has $\dfrac{2}{3}$ as many fruits on it as the tomato plant has. The tomato plant has $9$ fruits on it.   **How many fruits does the pepper plant have on it?**   fruits

hints.content: A tomato plant has $9$ fruits on it.

images.alt: 9 circles.

hints.content: The pepper plant has $\dfrac23$ as many fruits as the tomato plant.  Let's break the $9$ tomatoes into $3$ equal groups.

images.alt: The same 9 circles in 3 groups of 3.

hints.content: The pepper plant has $2$ of the $3$ equal groups.    There are $6$ peppers.

images.alt: 6 circles in 2 groups of 3.

hints.content: Since the pepper plant has $\dfrac{2}{3}$ as many fruits, we can also multiply $9 \times \dfrac{2}{3}$ to find how many fruits are on each plant.  $\begin{align} &9 \times \dfrac{2}{3}\\\\ =&\dfrac{9 \times 2} {3}\\\\ =&\dfrac{18}{3}\\\\ =&\dfrac61\\\\ =&{6} \end{align}$
The pepper plant has $6$ fruits on it.

question.content: Sophie's dog has $8$ chew toys. Annie's dog has $\dfrac{1}{4}$ as many chew toys as Sophie's dog.  **How many chew toys does Annie's dog have?**   chew toys

hints.content: Sophie's dog has $8$ chew toys.

images.alt: 8 circles.

hints.content: Annie's dog has $\dfrac14$ as many chew toys as Sophie's dog.  Let's break the $8$ chew toys into $4$ equal groups.

images.alt: The same 8 circles in 4 groups of 2.

hints.content: Annie's dog has $1$ of the $4$ equal groups.    There are $2$ chew toys.

images.alt: 2 circles in 1 group of 2.

hints.content: Since Annie's dog has $\dfrac{1}{4}$ as many chew toys, we can also multiply $8 \times \dfrac{1}{4}$ to find how many chew toys she has.  $\begin{align} &8 \times \dfrac{1}{4}\\\\ =&\dfrac{8 \times 1} {4}\\\\ =&\dfrac{8}{4}\\\\ =&{2} \end{align}$
Annie's dog has $2$ chew toys.

question.content: Mark and Damien were in a hot dog eating contest. Mark ate $12$ hot dogs. Damien ate $\dfrac46$ as many hot dogs as Mark.  **How many hot dogs did Damien eat?**   hot dogs

hints.content: Mark ate $12$ hot dogs.   [[☃ image 1]]

images.alt: An array of 12 hot dogs arranged in 6 rows with 2 hot dogs in each row.

hints.content: Damien ate $\dfrac46$ as many hot dogs as Mark..  Let's break the $12$ hot dogs into $6$ equal groups.

images.alt: The same 12 hot dogs in 6 groups of 2.

hints.content: Damien ate $4$ of the $6$ equal groups.       There are $8$ hot dogs.

images.alt: 8 hot dogs in 4 groups of 2.

hints.content: Since Damien ate $\dfrac{4}{6}$ as many hot dogs, we can also multiply $12 \times \dfrac{4}{6}$ to find how many hot dogs he ate.  $\begin{align} &12 \times \dfrac{4}{6}\\\\ =&\dfrac{12 \times 4} {6}\\\\ =&\dfrac{48}{6}\\\\ =&{8} \end{align}$
Damien ate $8$ hot dogs.

question.content: A gardener digs a flower bed that is  $7$ meters long and $\dfrac{3}{4}$ meter wide.   **What is the area of the flower bed?**   square meters

hints.content: The flower bed is $\blueD7$ meters long.   [[☃ image 1]]

images.alt: A rectangle with one side length labeled 7 meters

hints.content: The flower bed is $\maroonD{\dfrac{3}{4}}$ meter wide.    [[☃ image 1]]

images.alt: A rectangle with one side length labeled 7 meters blue and one width labeled three-fourths meter.

hints.content: $\begin{align} \text{Area of rectangle }&=\text{length} \times \text{width}\\\\ &=\blueD7\times\maroonD{\dfrac34}\\\\ &=\dfrac{\blueD7\times\maroonD3}{\maroonD4}\\\\ &=\dfrac{21}{4} \end{align}$
The area of the flower bed is $\dfrac{21}4$ square meters.

question.content: Dina is getting a new rug for her hallway. The rug is $\dfrac56$ meter wide and $9$ meters long.  **What is the area of the rug?**   square meters

hints.content: The rug is $\blueD9$ meters long.    [[☃ image 1]]

images.alt: A rectangle with one side length labeled 9 meters.

hints.content: The rug is $\maroonD{\dfrac{5}{6}}$ meter wide.   [[☃ image 1]]

images.alt: A rectangle with one side length labeled 9 meters and a width labeled five-sixth meter.

hints.content: $\begin{align} \text{Area of rectangle }&=\text{length} \times \text{width}\\\\ &=\blueD9\times\maroonD{\dfrac56}\\\\ &=\dfrac{\blueD9\times\maroonD5}{\maroonD6}\\\\ &=\dfrac{45}{6} \end{align}$
The area of the rug is $\dfrac{45}6$ square meters.  We can also write $\dfrac{45}6$ as $\dfrac{15}2$ square meters.

question.content: Chris is putting new baseboards in his bedroom. The baseboard is $15$ meters long and $\dfrac9{10}$ meter wide.  **What is the area of the baseboard?**   square meters

hints.content: The baseboard is $\blueD{15}$ meters long.  [[☃ image 1]]

images.alt: A rectangle with one side length labeled fifteen meters

hints.content: The basebooard is $\maroonD{\dfrac{9}{10}}$ meter wide.    [[☃ image 1]]

images.alt: A rectangle with one side length labeled fifteen meters and one width labeled nine-tenth meter.

hints.content: $\begin{align} \text{Area of rectangle }&=\text{length} \times \text{width}\\\\ &=\blueD{15}\times\maroonD{\dfrac9{10}}\\\\ &=\dfrac{\blueD{15}\times\maroonD9}{\maroonD{10}}\\\\ &=\dfrac{135}{10} \end{align}$
The area of the baseboard is $\dfrac{135}{10}$ square meters.  We can also write $\dfrac{135}{10}$ as $\dfrac{27}2$ square meters.
